title-group.article-title: Re: Sharma P, Hardwicke J, Khan M. A safety device to prevent injury from Kirschner wires. J Hand Surg Eur. 2011, 36: 605–7

contrib-group.aff: Orthopaedic SpRs, East of England Rotation, UK

permissions.copyright-holder: The British Society for Surgery of the Hand

body.p: We were interested to read Sharma, Hardwicke, and Khan’s survey of plastic surgical trainees’ methods for protecting the surgical team from K-wire injuries. We learned the following technique from a spinal surgeon. The protective sheath of a hypodermic needle containing a small amount of bone wax is placed over the protruding K-wire to protect the surgical team. It can easily be reapplied, as required, throughout the case, and the bone wax prevents it from becoming inadvertently dislodged (Halsey et al (2010)). This method shares all the benefits of the modified 10 ml syringe proposed by Sharma et al., as it is smooth, radiolucent, inexpensive, easily available, and easy to apply. We feel that the lighter weight and lower profile of a needle sheath is an advantage in confined operative fields.

ref.citation: HalseyT GriffithsE RaiA . Intra-operative protection from exposed k-wires: technical tip. Ann R Coll Surg Engl. 2010, 92: 441.

contrib-group.aff: Addenbrooke’s Hospital, Cambridge, and Birmingham Children’s Hospital, Birmingham,UK

body.p: We would like to thank Halsey and Griffiths for their response to our letter. However, in one of the authors’ experience, while indeed producing a very low profile protector, the bone wax technique is more “fiddly” and, as Halsey and Griffiths have pointed out (Halsey et al (2010)), often requires reapplication intraoperatively. Clearly both techniques have their merits and which one a given surgeon uses will come down to personal preference.
